content.description: This is a lay down start to the right side of the classic face. It starts underneath the boulder on a flake, start with feet back in the cave somewhere, then pull out the lip. There is a hard mantle on tiny crimps right there at the bottom, and then you're into the stand start, which goes at about V8.
content.location: It is right of the classic V4 face climb under the obvious cave where kids like to play.

content.description: Climb the less-than-vertical, rounded arete with thin slab features. The crux is at mid-height. There's more than one way to climb this one; the grade depends on which side of the arete you climb.
content.protection: There is a single glue-in bolt for toproping this and other routes on the boulder. A pad and spotter will suffice for most boulderers, because the rock ain't that tall.
content.location: On the Little Agassiz Rock, this is the westernmost arete that faces the main loop trail.

content.description: The Vault is essentially a hanging sit start on the far left end face of Little Agassiz.Move up and left around the steep undercut arête eventually matching on a crimp bar. Power straight up the arête using a slopey sidepull, and make a high topout. It has great movement and exposure.
content.location: Start at the far left end face of the Little Agassiz Boulder, and move left and then up the arete.

content.description: Stand start the lower angled face using finesse, balance, and technique to reach the slopey lip with your left hand, and then begin a sloper-mantle sequence.
content.location: Looking at the photo, this climb starts on the right side of the pad and more or less trends up the center of the face depicted by the shadow of the tree.

content.description:
Climb the more rounded arete 5 or so feet from the heavily featured arete.  There are several ways of doing it, but all involve nice, delicate face moves up less than vertical rock.   

  The grade is a generalization and line dependent.
content.protection: Pads and spotter.  This is highball boulder problem.  It can also be TRed off a single glue-in at the top.
content.location: There are sort of two northwest aretes on Little Agassiz rock.  One is heavily featured and closest to the nearby smaller quarried boulder, the other is to the right and more rounded.  This is the latter arete.

content.description:
Highball the nice back face of Little Agassiz via several variations.  Likely the most obvious line starts in the center at a good flake/rail.  Make multiple high-step/long-reach moves to decent holds and top out trending vaguely left through a weakness and an easy top-out. 

  An obvious hold at mid-height is having some issues.  A good chunk broke under the strain of my Herculean crimp and what is left is in a state of flux.  Still it is a fun face climb.   

  To the right of this looks harder (and funner) and to the left looks easier.
content.protection: Pads and spotter.  Or TR via glue-in above.
content.location: This is the rear face that face away from the path back toward the car.

content.description: Climb Little Agassiz Rock's arete closest to Big Agassiz Rock, if you don't know which direction is northwest. This is a classic, moderate problem. The crux is leaving the ground.
content.protection: Pad and spotter. There is a single glue-in bolt for toperope anchors, probably unnecessary for most boulderers.
content.location: Climb the northwest arete. Downclimb the back. For orientation, there's a big quarry/industrial park to the east that you can see from the top of this hill.

content.description:
This is on a severely under-appreciated section at Agassiz, considering how much lichen grows on this problem! 

  Stand start on good, opposing sidepulls with bad feet just left of the Southwest Arete, and work your way left a couple steps (crux) until you get into the green streak in the center of the face where you'll find a fun pinch hold. Using a couple balancy mantles and underclings, head straight up for a relieving topout.  

  This has good movement, is technique intensive, is tall, and has an easy topout. This is a great problem to run laps on!
content.protection: Pad and spotter, or you could TR this with a little creativity (bolts are there, but I think they're not really in the right place, if my memory is correct).
content.location: The middle of the West face of Little Agassiz, right up a proud vertical face with a green streak in the center. Start either on opposing sidepulls to the right, or on a crimp/flake down to the left (harder)

content.description: Sit start the left side of the Little Agassiz face pretty much directly at the spot which has some green lichen. Move straight up and slightly left on thin edges and crimps. Snag a left hand sloper at the lip, and traverse left to a high ball exit or top out straight above. It is the same rating either way.

At the high, clear, windswept hilltop you will see Little Agassiz rock first and foremost. It is a large, proud, sheer-sided boulder directly on your left as you crest the hill.    There are other boulders in the area. Some of them provide decent bouldering. Look around.
